column2: ## Q1.1 — Create a function that simulates the results of flipping one coin once, name it as flip_coin
flip_coin <- function() sample(c("H","T"), size = 1, replace = TRUE)
## Q1.2 — Use the function to find the results of flipping a coin 10 times.
set.seed(2102) # for reproducibility in your submission
## Q2.3 — Create a function that simulates the results of rolling two dice once. Where the first die
##is a fair 6-sided die and the second die is unfair 5-sided die of your own choice.
##Excluding a die with the set of numbers (1,2,3,4,5), make a random selection of
##numbers in the five-sided die. Name the function as roll_dice
die1 <- sample(1:6, size = 1, replace = TRUE) # fair d6
die2 <- sample(c(1,2,3,4,5), size = 1, replace = TRUE) # uniform d5 on chosen set
## Q2.4 —Use the function to find the results of rolling the two dice 5 times.
die2 <- sample(c(2, 3, 5, 7, 9), 1, replace = TRUE)  # faces مباشرة
## Q2.5 —Assuming the following events are defined as below:
## A = ‘at least one of the dice shows number 1’
## B = ‘ same number on the two dice’
P_B_and_C <- mean(sapply(simul_rol, function(x) x[1] == x[2] & x[1] %% 2 == 1))
## Q3.6 —Merge the two functions in one new function, such that, if the results of the ##flip_coin
##gives Head, get the results of rolling die #1 alone, while if the results is Tail, get the
##results of rolling {die #1 + die #2}, name the function flip_and_rol{
